facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1227 of 1972 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION -Civil Appeal No. 1227 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 9th December 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION -Civil Appeal No. 1227 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970. N Pliadke, Naunit Lal and Lalita Kohli, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellants and first nineteen respondents and respondents 22 to 24 are employees in the Agriculture Department of the State of Maharashtra following reorganisation of States on 1st November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants and the first nineteen respondents and respondents 22 to 24 are at present the employees in the Agriculture Department of the State of Maharashtra following reorganisation of States on 1st November, 1956. Respondents 1 to 19 were the original petitioners in S.C.A. No. 1354 of 1970.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 19 were officers from the former Hyderabad State prior to the States Reorganisation Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 to 19 were the original petitioners in S.C.A. No. 1354 of 1970. They were officers from the former Hyderabad State piior to the States Reorganisation Act, 1956,  briefly called the Act . They prayed in their said application for a writ to set aside the Bombay Governments Resolutions of 17th February, 1958

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 19 prayed for writ to set aside Bombay Government Resolutions of 17th February 1958 and 16th May 1969.

anchor.surface_text: They were officers from the former Hyderabad State piior to the States Reorganisation Act, 1956,  briefly called the Act . They prayed in their said application for a writ to set aside the Bombay Governments Resolutions of 17th February, 1958 and 16th May, 1969 and the provisional gradation list of 27th September, 1969

facts.text: Provisional gradation list issued on 27th September 1969.

anchor.surface_text: and 16th May, 1969 and the provisional gradation list of 27th September, 1969 and the promotion orders of 5th and 6th June, 1970 and other companysequential reliefs. They had impleaded in the said application five respondents, the first two being the State of Maharashtra and the Director of Agriculture, Maharashtra

facts.text: Promotion orders issued on 5th and 6th June 1970.

anchor.surface_text: the provisional gradation list of 27th September, 1969 and the promotion orders of 5th and 6th June, 1970 and other companysequential reliefs.

facts.text: States Reorganisation on 1st November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: the employees in the Agriculture Department of the State of Maharashtra following reorganisation of States on 1st November, 1956.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 3 to 5 did not appear to contest the application in Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the remaining three respondents were the three Agricultural Officers impleaded in a representative capacity by leave of the High Court under order 1, rule 8, Civil Procedure Code. These respondents  Nos. 3 to 5  did number appear to companytest the. application in the Bombay High Court

facts.text: State of Maharashtra and Director of Agriculture went by default in SCA 1354/1970.

anchor.surface_text: Even the first two respondents, namely, the State of Maharashtra and the Director of Agriculture, went by default, although a belated prayer to enter appearance had been made through companynsel on behalf of the State of Maharashtra after companymencement of arguments, on the day of final hearing, which was, however, rejected by the. High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court disposed of SCA 1354/1970 ex parte on merits in favour of applicants on 9th December 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The application was then disposed of, ex parte, on merits by the High Court in favour of the applicants. It is number disputed that the order of the High Court directly affects the interests of the present appellants, who are Agricultural Officers from the Madhya Pradesh region.

facts.text: Appellants are Agricultural Officers from the Madhya Pradesh region.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the order of the High Court directly affects the interests of the present appellants, who are Agricultural Officers from the Madhya Pradesh region. From Bombay we may number turn to the Nagpur Bench of the said High Court.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 and three other Agricultural Officers lodged Special Civil Application No. 361 of 1964 at Nagpur Bench.

anchor.surface_text: From Bombay we may number turn to the Nagpur Bench of the said High Court. There the appellant No. 1 and three other Agricultural Officers lodged a Special Civil Application No. 361 of 1964 impleading the State of Maharashtra and 88 other respondents, including the present respondents 1 to 19.

facts.text: Nagpur Bench allowed SCA 361/1964 on 6th December 1967, quashed Government resolution dated 9-9-1960 and combined seniority list dated 22-8-1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Nagpur Bench of the High Court allowed the Writ application by its judgment and order dated 6th December, 1967 and the operative part of the same may be quoted. Accordingly, we allow the petition and quash the resolution of the Government dated 9-9- 1960 and companybined seniority list issued by the Government on 22-8-1962.

facts.text: Nagpur Bench quashed order of absorption dated 11.5.1962.

anchor.surface_text: The neces sary companyrespondence of quashing of these two orders is that the intermediate order of absorption which is necessary step after inter se seniority and gradation list can be companypiled is also to be quashed. Accordingly, we quash the order of absorption, so far as these petitioners and respondents No. 3 to 89 are companycerned, dated 11.5. 1962.

facts.text: Respondents from Hyderabad region preferred appeal No. 1366 of 1968 against Nagpur Bench judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, who were Agricultural Officers from Hyderabad region,, preferred an appeal against the judgment of the Nagpur Bench being No. 1366 of 1968 in this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed withdrawal of appeal No. 1366/1968 on 23rd January 1969 without prejudice to make representations under section 115 of States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: They were, however, allowed by this Court on 23rd January, 1969, to withdraw the same without prejudice to all parties affected to make representations to the Government in accordance with section 115 of the States Reorganisation Act,. 1956

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra passed Resolution on 16th May 1969 giving new equation of posts.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Maharashtra passed a Resolution of 16th May, 1969, purporting to be an order giving new equation of posts in the Agricultural Department in pursuance of which a gradation list was made on 27th September, 1969.

facts.text: Gradation list made on 27th September 1969 pursuant to Resolution of 16th May 1969.

anchor.surface_text: purporting to be an order giving new equation of posts in the Agricultural Department in pursuance of which a gradation list was made on 27th September, 1969. Then followed certain companysequential orders of promotion of 5th and 6th June, 1970.

facts.text: Bombay High Court made absolute the rule in SCA 1354/1970 on 9th December 1971.

anchor.surface_text: This, as already numbericed, led to the Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970 at the instance of respondents, 1 to 19 and the operative part of this impugned order of 9th December, 1971, is in the following terms - For the reasons stated in the accompanying judgment, the Court makes absolute with companyts the rule granted by it on 30.6.70

facts.text: Appellant and another filed SCA No. 1126 of 1971 in Nagpur Bench challenging Resolution of 16th May 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and another person had also filed Special Civil Application No. 1126 of 1971 in the Nagpur Bench for quashing the Resolution of the Bombay Government of 16th May, 1969, on certain grounds. That matter is still pending in the Nagpur Bench.

facts.text: SCA 1126/1971 is still pending in Nagpur Bench.

anchor.surface_text: That matter is still pending in the Nagpur Bench. The respondents 1 to 19 were impleaded as respondents in that application and although they had been served, they did number file any return when the said application came up for hearing at Nagpur on 2nd February, 1972.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Bombay High Court judgment of 9th December 1971 and directs restoration of SCA 1354/1970.

anchor.surface_text: Without, therefore, going into the various points raised before us, we set aside the impugned judgment and order of the Bombay High Court of 9th December, 1971 and direct restoration of the Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970 to its file for disposal of the same in accordance with law after giving opportunity to all the parties companycerned.

facts.text: Supreme Court directs respondents 1 to 19 to implead Central Government and appellants in SCA 1354/1970.

anchor.surface_text: We further direct that respondents 1 to 19 shall take steps in the High Court to implead the Central Government as well as the present appellants and all other officers affected by the orders sought to be quashed in the Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970 The appeal is allowed on the terms indicated above.

facts.text: High Court rejected State's prayer to enter appearance belatedly.

anchor.surface_text: although a belated prayer to enter appearance had been made through companynsel on behalf of the State of Maharashtra after companymencement of arguments, on the day of final hearing, which was, however, rejected by the. High Court.

under Article 226 of the Constitution. The appellants and the first nineteen respondents and respondents 22 to 24 are at present the employees in the Agriculture Department of the State of Maharashtra following reorganisation of States on 1st November, 1956.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970. N Pliadke, Naunit Lal and Lalita Kohli, for the appellant.

This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay of 9th December, 1971, in Special Civil Application  S.C.A.  No. 1354 of 1970 under Article 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The Central Government under section 115 of the States Reorganisation Act has exclusive authority to determine principles governing equation of posts, prepare common gradation lists by integration of services, ensure fair and equitable treatment, and give opportunities for representations to affected parties.

anchor.surface_text: under section 115 of the Act has to determine the principles governing equation of posts and prepare common gradation lists by integration of services and in doing so to ensure fair and equitable treatment to all persons concerned. The Central Government is also required to give opportunities to the parties affected to make their representations.  See D. Rajian Raj Others v. Union of India others  1  N. Subba Rao etc. v. Union of India and Others  2  and Union of India Anr. v. P. K. Roy Ors.  3   .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled law citing precedents; Central Government is final authority for service integration post-reorganisation.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in directing the State Government to determine equation of posts and absorption, and in fixing a time limit leading to automatic entitlement, as these functions belong exclusively to the Central Government under the States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court cannot clothe upon itself the authority for performing the functions which are specifically and expressly intended to be the obligation and duty of the Central Government under the Act. The High Court is, therefore. number right in two matters namely, in directing the State Government to do that which under the, provisions of the Act is within the domain of the Central Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court lacks jurisdiction to perform Central Government's statutory obligations under S.115 SRA; view clearly erroneous.

holdings.text: There was violation of principles of natural justice as the High Court disposed of the writ petition ex parte without adequate opportunity to the State and affected parties, and rejected rehearing despite sufficient cause.

anchor.surface_text: there is clear violation of the principles of natural justice in disposing of the writ petition by the High Court, ex parte, and in number reviewing its order when sufficient cause was shown by the appellants herein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex parte disposal in representative writ affecting many without impleading actually affected persons or allowing rehearing despite High Court noting sufficient cause.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in not allowing rehearing of the writ petition and opportunity to all parties, especially in a representative proceeding without impleading affected persons.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed we are satisfied on reading these affidavits that there was sufficient cause for rehearing the Special Civil Application, but on perusal of the affidavit in re and hearing counsel for the State rejected the said petition. ... We are number satisfied that the High Court was right in number allowing an opportunity to the petitioners as well as to the State to canvass their respective points of view before, it against the writ application,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court itself found sufficient cause but rejected; mandatory to hear affected parties and State in service matters heard representatively.

holdings.text: The impugned judgment and order of the Bombay High Court dated 9th December 1971 is set aside; Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970 is restored for disposal in accordance with law after hearing all parties.

anchor.surface_text: Without, therefore, going into the various points raised before us, we set aside the impugned judgment and order of the Bombay High Court of 9th December, 1971 and direct restoration of the Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970 to its file for disposal of the same in accordance with law after giving opportunity to all the parties concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to procedural irregularities and natural justice violations; not deciding merits but remanding for fresh consideration.

holdings.text: Respondents 1 to 19 are directed to implead the Central Government, present appellants, and all other affected officers in SCA No. 1354 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: We further direct that respondents 1 to 19 shall take steps in the High Court to implead the Central Government as well as the present appellants and all other officers affected by the orders sought to be quashed in the Special Civil Application No. 1354 of 1970 The appeal is allowed on the terms indicated above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central Government necessary party for matters under S.115; all affected must be heard.
